explanation: Fleeing or attempting to evade law enforcement that results in serious injury carries severe penalties under California law, including imprisonment in state prison. The punishment is particularly severe when injuries occur, emphasizing the dangerous nature of this offense.

questionText: What should a driver do who is stopped at an intersection and wants to make a left turn?
answerA: Turn immediately if there are no pedestrians
answerB: Take the right-of-way turn before oncoming traffic
answerC: Give the right-of-way to any approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous
explanation: When turning left at an intersection, check for pedestrians and give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous. Look both ways (left-right-left) and begin your turn when it is safe.

questionText: In addition to setting your parking brake, what should you do when parking on a hill?
answerA: Make sure the front vehicle wheels are parallel to the road
answerB: Make sure your vehicle is left in the "neutral" position
answerC: Make sure your vehicle is in the "park" position or in gear
explanation: When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to equipment failure. Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission. This provides an additional safeguard against the vehicle rolling.

questionText: You are under 18 years of age and have had your license for eight months. You may drive:
explanation: As a provisional driver under 18 years old, you cannot drive between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. during the first 12 months you have your license. Since the driver has had their license for eight months, they are still within the first 12 months and must follow this restriction.

questionText: Where should you begin a left turn from a one-way street onto a one-way street?
answerA: The lane closest to the center of the street
answerC: You can turn from any lane
explanation: Left turn from a one-way street onto a one-way street: Start the turn from the far-left lane. Bicyclists can legally use the left turn lane for their left turns. If there are three or more lanes in your direction of travel, you may end your turn in any lane that is open.

questionText: You are required to notify DMV by filing a Report of Traffic Accident Occuring in California (SR-1) form if:
answerA: You allowed a licensed driver from another state to drive your vehicle
answerB: You were involved in a collision with more than $1,000 in damages
answerC: You failed to pay your registration fees
explanation: If you are in a collision, you must report it to DMV within 10 days if the collision caused more than $1,000 in damage to property or anyone was injured or killed. Each driver must file a Report of Traffic Accident Occurring in California (SR 1) with DMV whether or not you caused the collision.

questionText: At what point during a rainfall are roads slippery on a hot day?
answerA: Immediately after it has stopped raining
answerC: When it has been raining for a few hours
explanation: When it starts to rain, the pavement can be very slippery. Slow down at the first sign of rain, drizzle, or snow on the road. This is especially true if it has been dry and hot for some time, because oil and dust on the road's surface have not been washed away.

questionText: When is it legal to drive off the road to pass another vehicle?
answerA: If the vehicle ahead is turning left
answerB: It is not legal under any conditions
answerC: If there are two or more one-way lanes
explanation: Never drive off the paved or main-traveled part of the road to pass. This is prohibited under all conditions to ensure safety on the roadway.

questionText: If you take your vision test with corrective lenses, your driver's license will:
answerA: Be marked with a corrective lenses restriction
answerB: Be valid for only one year
explanation: If you take your vision test with corrective or contact lenses, your driver's license will have a corrective lenses restriction. This means you must wear your corrective lenses when driving.

questionText: How many attempts are you allowed to pass the knowledge test before you must reapply?
explanation: You are allowed three attempts to pass the knowledge test before you must reapply. Minors must wait seven days to retake a failed knowledge test, not including the day of the failure.

questionText: Physicians are required to report which of the following conditions to the DMV?
explanation: Physicians are required to report patients, who are at least 14 years old, to DMV for medical conditions that may affect your ability to drive safely, such as lapse of consciousness.

questionText: What is the speed limit in an alley?
explanation: An alley is any road no wider than 25 feet that is used to access the rear or side entrances of buildings or properties. The speed limit in an alley is 15 mph.

questionText: It is illegal to wear a headset or earplugs in both ears while driving:
explanation: It is illegal to wear a headset or earplugs in both ears while driving. You must be able to hear horns, sirens, motorcycles, or screeching tires that may alert you of hazards.

questionText: When entering a two-way center left turn lane, you may only drive in it for:
explanation: You may enter a two-way center left turn lane within 200 feet of the turn. You must respect the right-of-way of any vehicle, bicyclist, or motorcyclist already in the lane.

questionText: If a minor fails the behind-the-wheel drive test, they must wait how long before retaking it?
explanation: Minors must wait 14 days to retake a failed behind-the-wheel drive test, not including the day of the failure.

questionText: It is illegal to smoke in a vehicle when:
answerA: A minor is in the vehicle
explanation: You must not smoke when a minor is in the vehicle. You can be fined for smoking in a vehicle with a minor present.

questionText: What does a diamond-shaped sign on a truck indicate?
answerB: The truck's load may be dangerous
answerD: The truck is carrying medical supplies
explanation: A diamond-shaped sign on a truck means that the truck's load may be dangerous (gas, explosives, etc.). Vehicles with these signs must stop before crossing railroad tracks.

questionText: Lane splitting is:
answerB: Legal for motorcycles to share lanes with other vehicles
explanation: It is legal to share lanes with motorcycles. This is known as lane splitting.

questionText: When you see signs marked 'NEV ROUTE' or 'NEV USE ONLY', what should you watch for?
explanation: Signs marked 'NEV USE ONLY' or 'NEV ROUTE' indicate you should watch for slow-moving vehicles. Neighborhood Electric Vehicles (NEVs) and Low-speed Vehicles (LSVs) reach a maximum speed of 25 mph.

questionText: You can be ticketed if you interrupt a:
explanation: A funeral procession is led by a traffic officer and has the right-of-way. All vehicles taking part in the procession have windshield markers to identify them and have their headlights on. You can be ticketed if you interrupt a funeral procession.

questionText: DMV places restrictions on a driver's license to:
answerB: Ensure a driver operates within their ability
explanation: DMV places restrictions on a driver's license to ensure a driver is operating a vehicle within their ability. Restrictions placed on your driving privilege will be reasonable and necessary for your safety and the safety of others.

questionText: Tires must have at least how much tread depth for a behind-the-wheel drive test?
explanation: The tires must have at least 1/32-inch of uniformed tread depth. The use of a donut tire is not allowed during a drive test.

questionText: To turn around and drive in the opposite direction on a narrow two-lane road, you should:
answerA: Make a U-turn at any time
answerB: Use a turnout area or wait until you reach a safe place to turn around
explanation: Some two-lane roads have special turnout areas or lanes. Merge into these areas or lanes to allow cars behind you to pass. You must use a turnout area or lane to let other vehicles pass when you are driving slowly on a two-lane road, where passing is unsafe, and there are five or more vehicles following you.

questionText: What is the maximum speed for Neighborhood Electric Vehicles (NEVs) and Low-speed Vehicles (LSVs)?
explanation: NEVs and LSVs reach a maximum speed of 25 mph. They are restricted from roads where the speed limit is greater than 35 mph.

questionText: On what roads are NEVs and LSVs restricted from traveling?
answerA: Roads where the speed limit is greater than 25 mph
answerB: Roads where the speed limit is greater than 35 mph
answerC: Roads where the speed limit is greater than 45 mph
explanation: NEVs and LSVs reach a maximum speed of 25 mph. They are restricted from roads where the speed limit is greater than 35 mph.

questionText: It is against the law to intentionally scare:
explanation: Horse-drawn vehicles and people riding horses or other animals are allowed to share the road with motor vehicles. It is against the law to intentionally scare horses or livestock.

questionText: When approaching stationary emergency vehicles with flashing lights, you must:
explanation: When approaching a stationary emergency vehicle with flashing emergency signal lights (hazard lights), move over and slow down.

questionText: You can be arrested if you drive to the scene of a:
explanation: You can be arrested if you drive to the scene of a fire, collision, or other disaster. When you do this, you are getting in the way of firefighters, ambulance crews, or other rescue and emergency personnel.

questionText: At least how far must you ride from the airbag cover to maintain full control of your vehicle?
explanation: Ride at least 10 inches from the airbag cover, as long as you can maintain full control of your vehicle. Measure from the center of the steering wheel to your breastbone.

questionText: It is illegal to leave a child under what age unattended in a vehicle?
explanation: It is illegal to leave a child who is six years old or younger unattended in a vehicle. A child may be left under the supervision of a person who is at least 12 years old.

questionText: Under what age must a child be supervised by a person at least 12 years old if left in a vehicle?
explanation: It is illegal to leave a child who is six years old or younger unattended in a vehicle. A child may be left under the supervision of a person who is at least 12 years old.

questionText: How far ahead should you look when driving on city streets?
explanation: To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle. This helps you be aware of your surroundings and make good decisions to react to hazards on the road.

questionText: The maximum speed limit on most California highways is:
explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the ideal maximum speed limit on most California highways is 65 mph. It is 55 mph on a two-lane undivided highway and for vehicles towing trailers.

questionText: When wet, which areas tend to freeze first and remain icy longest?
answerB: Areas shaded by trees or buildings
explanation: Shade from trees or buildings can hide icy spots on cold, wet days. These areas freeze first and dry out last.

questionText: If you are convicted of dumping or abandoning animals on a highway, you can be punished by:
answerB: A fine of up to $1,000, six months in jail, or both
explanation: You must not dump or abandon animals on a highway. This crime is punishable by a fine of up to $1,000, six months in jail, or both.

questionText: When transporting animals in the back of a pickup truck, you must:
answerC: Only transport animals during the day
explanation: You must not transport animals in the back of a pickup or other truck unless the animal is properly secured. This prevents the animal from falling, jumping, or being thrown from the vehicle.

questionText: It is illegal to throw which of the following from your vehicle?
explanation: You must not throw a cigarette, cigar, or other flaming or glowing substance from your vehicle.

questionText: When are you required to show proof of financial responsibility (insurance)?
answerB: When you drive and for a drive test
explanation: You must have your proof of financial responsibility (insurance) when you drive and for a drive test. If you get into a collision, you must show proof to the other drivers involved in the collision.

questionText: The minimum insurance coverage required for a single death or injury is:
explanation: Your insurance must cover at least $30,000 for a single death or injury.

questionText: If you cannot afford liability insurance, you may be eligible for:
answerC: California Low Cost Automobile Insurance Program
explanation: If you cannot afford liability insurance, you may be eligible for the California Low Cost Automobile Insurance Program.

questionText: When should you avoid driving or limit your driving?
answerA: When you feel fatigued or drowsy
answerB: When taking medications that cause drowsiness
explanation: Fatigue and drowsiness can affect your vision and increase reaction time to hazards. Prescription and over-the-counter medications can make you an unsafe driver. You must be able to notice hazards in different types of lighting, judge distances, adjust to traffic speed, and read road signs.

questionText: The Hand-to-Hand Steering method requires your hands to start at:
explanation: To use the Hand-to-Hand Steering (Push/Pull) method, start with your hands at 9 and 3 o'clock or 8 and 4 o'clock. Do not cross your hands over the middle of the steering wheel.

questionText: When using the Hand-to-Hand Steering method, you should:
answerA: Cross your hands over the steering wheel
answerB: Not cross your hands over the middle of the steering wheel
answerD: Keep your hands at 10 and 2 o'clock
explanation: To use the Hand-to-Hand Steering (Push/Pull) method, start with your hands at 9 and 3 o'clock or 8 and 4 o'clock. Do not cross your hands over the middle of the steering wheel. Keep your hands in these positions, even when making turns.

questionText: One-hand steering is appropriate when:
answerB: Turning while backing up to see where you are going
explanation: There are only two situations that may require steering with one hand: when you are turning while backing up to see where you are going behind you (place your hand at the 12 o'clock position), or when you are operating vehicle controls that require you to remove a hand from the steering wheel.

questionText: On a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
explanation: Rain, snow, or mud can make the roads slippery. Drive more slowly than you would on a dry road. Adjust your speed for different conditions: Wet road: Reduce your speed by 5 to 10 mph.

questionText: On packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
explanation: Adjust your speed for different conditions: Packed snow: Reduce your speed by half.

questionText: On ice, you should reduce your speed to no more than:
explanation: Adjust your speed for different conditions: Ice: Reduce your speed to no more than 5 mph.

questionText: If your brakes get wet, you can dry them by:
answerB: Lightly pressing the accelerator and brake pedals at the same time
explanation: If your brakes get wet, you can dry them by lightly pressing the accelerator and brake pedals at the same time. Only do this until the brakes dry.

questionText: To safely share the road with light rail vehicles, you should:
answerA: Be aware of where they operate
answerB: Never turn in front of an approaching light rail vehicle
explanation: To safely share the road with light rail vehicles: be aware of where they operate, never turn in front of an approaching light rail vehicle, maintain a safe distance, and check for approaching light rail vehicles before you turn across the tracks.

questionText: Buildings, trees, and other items can cause blind spots for:
explanation: When driving near light rail vehicles, be aware that buildings, trees, and other items can cause blind spots for the operator.

questionText: Never try to pass a motorcycle:
answerB: In the same lane as you
explanation: Never try to pass a motorcycle in the same lane as you. Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicle drivers.

questionText: When possible, you should move to one side of your lane to:
answerB: Give motorcyclists more room to pass
explanation: When possible, move to one side of your lane to give motorcyclists more room to pass. Road conditions can cause motorcyclists to suddenly change speed or direction.

questionText: Before opening your door next to traffic, you should:
answerD: Wait for all traffic to pass
explanation: Check for motorcyclists before you open your door next to traffic. Motorcycles are smaller in size and harder to see so they easily disappear in vehicle blind spots.

questionText: When do provisional drivers (under 18) cannot drive between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m.?
answerA: During the first 6 months they have their license
answerB: During the first 9 months they have their license
answerC: During the first 12 months they have their license
explanation: As a provisional driver under 18 years old, you cannot drive between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. during the first 12 months you have your license.

questionText: A provisional driver can carry passengers under 20 years old only if:
answerA: They have had their license for one year
answerB: A parent, guardian, or licensed driver at least 25 years old rides with them
explanation: As a provisional driver, you cannot drive with passengers under 20 years old, unless your parent or guardian or other California-licensed driver (at least 25 years old) rides with you.

questionText: Cargo that extends more than 4 feet from the back-rear bumper must display:
answerB: A 12-inch red or fluorescent orange square flag
explanation: Cargo that extends more than 4 feet from the back-rear bumper of the vehicle must display a 12-inch red or fluorescent orange square flag. At night, this cargo must be marked with two red lights.

questionText: At night, cargo extending more than 4 feet from the back-rear bumper must be marked with:
explanation: Cargo that extends more than 4 feet from the back-rear bumper of the vehicle must display a 12-inch red or fluorescent orange square flag. At night, this cargo must be marked with two red lights.

questionText: The Mature Driver Improvement Program is an eight-hour course for drivers:
explanation: The Mature Driver Improvement Program is an eight-hour course for drivers 55 years old and older. It covers a range of topics that are of special interest to mature drivers.

questionText: Your Mature Driver Improvement Program certificate is valid for:
explanation: Your insurance company may offer discounts if you complete the Mature Driver Improvement Program. Your certificate is valid for three years. You can renew it by completing another four-hour course.

questionText: If you are 70 years old or older when your driver's license expires, you must:
answerB: Renew in person and pass a vision test
explanation: If you are 70 years old or older at the time your driver's license expires, you are required to renew your driver's license in person and pass a vision test. In some cases, other exams may be required.

questionText: Which of the following can be the basis for a driver reexamination?
explanation: A physical or mental condition or poor driver's record can be the basis for a reexamination, not a driver's age.

questionText: Who can submit a Request for Driver Reexamination form to the DMV?
answerB: A physician, law enforcement, or family member
explanation: Drivers with a physical or mental condition can be referred to DMV by a physician, law enforcement, or family member by submitting a completed Request for Driver Reexamination form.

questionText: DMV may immediately suspend or revoke your driving privilege if:
answerA: You fail to pay parking tickets
answerB: Your physical or mental condition presents an immediate threat to public safety
answerD: You have had your license for less than one year
explanation: DMV may immediately suspend or revoke your driving privilege if your physical or mental condition presents an immediate threat to public safety.

questionText: If you are 62 years old or older, you are eligible for:
explanation: If you are 62 years old or older, you are eligible for a no-fee Senior ID card. Drivers of any age who are unable to continue driving safely due to a physical or mental condition may be eligible to exchange their driver's license for a no-fee ID card.

questionText: It is illegal to drive a vehicle equipped with a video monitor visible to the driver unless it only displays:
answerC: Vehicle information, navigation, media player, or radio
explanation: You must not drive a vehicle equipped with a video monitor visible to the driver, unless it only displays vehicle information, a navigation system, media player, or radio.

questionText: A white-painted curb means:
answerA: Stop only long enough to pick up or drop off passengers
explanation: White curbs mean stop only long enough to pick up or drop off passengers.

questionText: A green-painted curb means:
explanation: Green curbs mean park for a limited time. The time limit may be posted on signs or painted on the curb.

questionText: At a yellow-painted curb, if you drive a noncommercial vehicle, you are usually required to:
explanation: Yellow curbs are for loading and unloading passengers and freight. Do not stop longer than the time posted. If you drive a noncommercial vehicle, you are usually required to stay with your vehicle.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of a fire hydrant?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within 15 feet of a fire hydrant or fire station driveway.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of an unmarked or marked crosswalk?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within 20 feet of an unmarked or marked crosswalk, or within 15 feet of a crosswalk where a curb extension is present.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of a sidewalk ramp for disabled persons?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within three feet of a sidewalk ramp for disabled persons.

questionText: When parallel parking, your vehicle must be within how many inches of the curb?
explanation: When parallel parking, your vehicle should be parallel and within 18 inches of the curb.

questionText: Bicyclists under what age must wear a helmet?
explanation: As a bicyclist, you must wear a helmet if under 18 years old.

questionText: Bicyclists must ride in what direction relative to traffic?
answerB: In the same direction as traffic
explanation: As a bicyclist, you must ride in the same direction as traffic.

questionText: When riding a bicycle at night, you must have a front lamp with a white light visible from:
explanation: When it is dark out, your bicycle must have a front lamp with a white light visible from 300 feet.

questionText: When riding a bicycle at night, the rear red reflector or light must be visible from:
explanation: When it is dark out, your bicycle must have a built-in rear red reflector, solid red light, or flashing red light that must be visible from 500 feet.

questionText: When riding a bicycle at night, reflectors on pedals, shoes, or ankles must be visible from:
explanation: When it is dark out, your bicycle must have a white or yellow reflector on each pedal, the bicyclist's shoes, or their ankles that must be visible from 200 feet.

questionText: A green arrow traffic signal means:
answerA: Caution, the light is about to change
answerB: You may make a protected turn in the direction the arrow is pointing
explanation: A green arrow means GO in the direction the arrow is pointing. The green arrow allows you to make a protected turn. Oncoming vehicles are stopped by a red traffic signal light.

questionText: A flashing yellow traffic signal light means:
explanation: A flashing yellow traffic signal light is a warning to proceed with caution. Slow down and be alert. You do not need to stop.

questionText: A flashing yellow arrow means:
answerC: You can turn, but your turn is not protected from other traffic
explanation: A flashing yellow arrow means you can turn, but your turn is not protected from other traffic. Proceed to turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and proceed with caution.

questionText: A yellow arrow means:
explanation: A yellow arrow means the protected turning time is ending. The signal will change soon. If you cannot stop safely or you are already in the intersection, cautiously complete your turn.

questionText: When a traffic light is not working, you should:
answerA: Proceed through the intersection without stopping
answerB: Stop as if the intersection is controlled by stop signs in all directions
answerC: Only stop if you see other vehicles
explanation: When a traffic light is not working, stop as if the intersection is controlled by STOP signs in all directions. Then proceed cautiously when it is safe to do so.

questionText: You should dim your high-beam headlights to low beams within how many feet of a vehicle you are following?
explanation: Dim your high-beam headlights to low beams within 500 feet of a vehicle coming toward you or within 300 feet of a vehicle you are following.

questionText: When is it illegal to drive using only parking lights?
explanation: It is illegal to drive using only parking lights. You must use your headlights when required by law.

questionText: You must use your headlights beginning when after sunset?
explanation: Use your headlights beginning 30 minutes after sunset until 30 minutes before sunrise.

questionText: If you need to use your windshield wipers due to fog, rain, or snow, you must:
explanation: If you need to use your windshield wipers due to fog, rain, or snow, you must turn on your low-beam headlights.

questionText: You should signal at least how many seconds before you change lanes on a freeway?
explanation: You should signal at least 100 feet before you turn or change lanes on city streets, and at least five seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.

questionText: At what distance can you see clearly enough to use high-beam headlights on narrow mountain roads?
explanation: Use your horn to alert oncoming traffic on narrow mountain roads where you cannot see at least 200 feet ahead.

questionText: Fines in highway construction or maintenance zones when workers are present are:
explanation: Fines are doubled in highway construction or maintenance zones when workers are present to ensure worker safety.

questionText: Fines for traffic violations in a work zone can be:
explanation: Fines for traffic violations in a work zone can be $1,000 or more.

questionText: Anyone convicted of assaulting a highway worker faces fines of up to:
explanation: Anyone convicted of assaulting a highway worker faces fines of up to $2,000 and imprisonment for up to one year.

questionText: If you are driving at night and you will know you are going the wrong way if:
answerB: The road reflectors shine red in your headlights
explanation: If you enter a roadway against traffic, DO NOT ENTER and WRONG WAY signs may be posted. If you are driving at night, you will know you are going the wrong way if the road reflectors shine red in your headlights.

questionText: When entering a highway from an on-ramp, you should:
answerA: Stop at the end of the ramp
answerB: Enter at or near the speed of traffic
answerC: Enter slowly and speed up gradually
answerD: Wait for a complete gap in traffic
explanation: When you enter a highway, you need to be at or near the speed of traffic. Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so without stopping unless absolutely necessary.

questionText: The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within:
explanation: The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 300 feet. A large vehicle traveling at the same speed can take up to 400 feet to stop.

questionText: A large vehicle traveling at 55 mph can take up to how many feet to stop?
explanation: The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 300 feet. A large vehicle traveling at the same speed can take up to 400 feet to stop. The heavier the vehicle and the faster it is moving, the longer it takes to safely stop.

questionText: If you cannot see a truck's side mirrors:
answerA: The truck driver can still see you
answerB: The truck driver cannot see you
explanation: Large vehicle and truck drivers have large blind spots, also called No Zones. In these areas, your vehicle can disappear from a large vehicle or truck driver's view. If you cannot see the truck's side mirrors, the truck driver cannot see you.

questionText: When a blind person pulls in their cane and steps away from the intersection, this gesture usually means:
explanation: When a blind person pulls in their cane and steps away from the intersection, this gesture usually means you may go.

questionText: On a steep narrow mountain road, which vehicle has the right-of-way when two vehicles meet and neither can pass?
explanation: If two vehicles meet on a steep narrow road and neither vehicle can pass, the vehicle facing uphill has the right-of-way. The vehicle facing downhill has more control when backing up the hill. The vehicle facing downhill should back up until the vehicle going uphill can pass.

questionText: When driving a hybrid or electric vehicle near blind pedestrians, you should be especially careful because:
answerA: These vehicles are harder to control
answerB: Blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby
explanation: Be careful when you are turning or backing up. This is particularly important if you are driving a hybrid or electric vehicle because blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby.

questionText: When you are tailgated, you should:
answerB: Brake suddenly to warn the driver
answerC: Maintain your course and speed, then merge right when safe to allow the tailgater to pass
answerD: Slow down gradually to force them to pass
explanation: If a tailgater is behind you, maintain your course and speed. Then, when safe to do so, merge right to change into another lane and allow the tailgater to pass.

questionText: When should you create more space in front of your vehicle?
answerA: When a tailgater is behind you
answerB: When following motorcyclists on metal surfaces
explanation: Create more space in front of your vehicle when: a tailgater is behind you, following motorcyclists on metal surfaces (bridge gratings, railroad tracks, etc.), and gravel.

questionText: If a vehicle merges in front of you too closely, you should:
answerC: Take your foot off the accelerator
explanation: If a vehicle merges in front of you too closely, take your foot off the accelerator. This creates space between you and the vehicle ahead.

questionText: To avoid last minute moves and hazards, you should scan the road at least how many seconds ahead of your vehicle?
explanation: To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle.

questionText: When another vehicle's lights are too bright at night, you should:
answerA: Look directly at the oncoming headlights
answerC: Look toward the right edge of your lane
explanation: If another vehicle's lights are too bright, do not look directly into the oncoming headlights. Look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

questionText: When you drive at night, you should remember that:
answerB: Motorcycles, pedestrians, and bicyclists are much harder to see
explanation: When you drive at night, remember that motorcycles, pedestrians, and bicyclists are much harder to see.

questionText: When you leave a brightly lit place at night, you should:
answerC: Drive slowly until your eyes adjust to the darkness
answerD: Turn on your parking lights only
explanation: When you leave a brightly lit place, drive slowly until your eyes adjust to the darkness.

questionText: When you see a vehicle with one light driving toward you at night, it could be:
answerC: A vehicle with a missing headlight
explanation: When a vehicle with one light drives toward you, drive as far to the right as possible. It could be a bicyclist, motorcyclist, or vehicle with a missing headlight.

questionText: Common distractions while driving include:
answerA: Looking at a phone or navigation system
explanation: Avoid distractions while you drive. Some common distractions are: looking at a phone, navigation system, children, and pets; changing music or volume; and applying makeup or shaving.

questionText: You must mount your cell phone on the windshield, dashboard, or center console so that it:
answerB: Does not block your view of the road
explanation: Mount your cell phone on the windshield, dashboard, or center console. It cannot block your view of the road.

questionText: Minors may use a cell phone while driving only to:
answerB: Make a call for emergency assistance
explanation: It is against the law for a minor to use a cell phone or electronic wireless device to answer calls and send or respond to text messages while driving. Exception: Minors may use a cell phone to make a call for emergency assistance.

questionText: If your vehicle stalls on railroad tracks and you do not see a train approaching, you should:
answerA: Stay in your vehicle and call for help
answerC: Exit your vehicle and dial the number on the railroad crossing posts
answerD: Push your vehicle off the tracks
explanation: If you do not see a train approaching and warning lights are not flashing, exit your vehicle. Dial the number located on the railroad crossing posts or metal control box near the tracks. Provide the crossing number (if posted). Tell them a vehicle is on the tracks. Then call 911.

questionText: California Highway Patrol Freeway Service Patrol (FSP) will NOT:
answerA: Provide a gallon of gas if you run out
answerB: Jump start your vehicle if the battery is dead
answerC: Tow your vehicle to a private repair service
explanation: FSP will not tow your vehicle to a private repair service or residence, recommend tow service companies or repair and body shops, tow motorcycles, or help vehicles which have been involved in a collision unless directed to by CHP.

questionText: You can reach the California Highway Patrol Freeway Service Patrol by dialing:
explanation: Call 511 for FSP information and assistance.

questionText: If your vehicle becomes disabled on the freeway, after pulling over safely, you should:
answerB: Exit on the right side and stay inside your vehicle with your seat belt on
explanation: If your vehicle stops working on the freeway, safely pull over to the right shoulder, exit on the right side if you must get out, dial 511 or locate a call box for assistance, return to your vehicle from the right side, and stay inside your vehicle with your seat belt on until help arrives.

questionText: When should you NOT pass another vehicle?
answerA: Within 100 feet of an intersection, bridge, or tunnel
answerB: When approaching a hill or curve where you cannot see if other traffic is approaching
explanation: Do not pass: if you are approaching a hill or curve and cannot see if other traffic is approaching; within 100 feet of an intersection, bridge, tunnel, railroad crossing, or other hazardous area; at crossroads and driveways; or unless you have enough space to return to your lane.

questionText: To safely pass on an open highway, you need to be able to see at least how far ahead?
explanation: You must judge whether you have enough space to pass whenever you approach an oncoming vehicle or bicyclist or a hill, curve, intersection, or road obstruction. To safely pass, the hill or curve should be at least one-third of a mile ahead.

questionText: To enter traffic from a full stop, you need a space of at least how far on city streets?
explanation: When entering traffic from a full stop, signal and leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic. To merge, enter, or exit traffic, you need a space that is half a block on city streets, which is about 150 feet.

questionText: To enter traffic on a highway, you need a space of at least:
explanation: When entering traffic from a full stop, signal and leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic. To merge, enter, or exit traffic, you need a space that is a full block on the highway, which is about 300 feet.

questionText: When making a left turn, you should keep your wheels pointed straight ahead until:
answerC: It is safe to start your turn
explanation: Keep your wheels pointed straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn. If your wheels are pointed to the left and a vehicle hits you from behind, you could be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questionText: When making a left turn from a two-way street onto a two-way street, you should:
answerB: Start in the left lane closest to the middle and end in the left lane closest to the middle
answerC: Start in the right lane and end in the left lane
answerD: Start in the left lane and end in any lane
explanation: Start the turn in the left lane closest to the middle of the street. To reduce the risk of collision, end the turn in the left lane closest to the middle of the street going in your vehicle's direction.

questionText: A dedicated right turn lane:
answerB: Does not merge into another lane and allows you to make a right turn without stopping
answerC: Requires you to stop at all times
explanation: A dedicated right turn lane does not merge into another lane and allows you to make a right turn without stopping. You may make your turn even if there is a red light for vehicles going straight through the intersection.

questionText: When making a U-turn in a residential district, no vehicles should be approaching you within:
explanation: You may make a U-turn in a residential district if no vehicles are approaching you within 200 feet.

questionText: You may make a U-turn:
answerA: At or on a railroad crossing
answerC: In front of a fire station
explanation: You may make a U-turn across a double yellow line, in a residential district if no vehicles are approaching you within 200 feet, at an intersection on a green traffic light or green arrow unless a NO U-TURN sign is posted, or on a divided highway if a center divider opening is provided.

questionText: You should NOT make a U-turn when you cannot see clearly for how many feet in each direction?
explanation: Never make a U-turn when you cannot see clearly for 200 feet in each direction.

questionText: Never make a U-turn in:
answerB: At or on a railroad crossing
answerC: In front of a fire station
explanation: Never make a U-turn where a NO U-TURN sign is posted, at or on a railroad crossing, on a divided highway by crossing a dividing section, when you cannot see clearly for 200 feet in each direction, on a one-way street, in front of a fire station, or in business districts except at an intersection or on a divided highway where an opening has been provided.

questionText: Two sets of solid double yellow lines spaced two or more feet apart are considered:
explanation: Two sets of solid double yellow lines spaced two or more feet apart are considered a barrier. Do not drive on or over this barrier, make a left turn, or make a U-turn across it, except at designated openings.

questionText: When exiting a highway, you should signal at least how many seconds before you exit?
explanation: When in the proper lane, signal five seconds (approximately 400 feet) before you exit. Know your exit and be aware of when it is approaching to allow time for safe lane changes.

questionText: You must report a collision to DMV within how many days if it caused more than $1,000 in damage to property?
explanation: If you are in a collision, you must report it to DMV within 10 days if the collision caused more than $1,000 in damage to property or anyone was injured or killed.

questionText: Which form must you file with DMV to report a collision?
answerA: Notice of Transfer and Release of Liability
answerB: Report of Traffic Accident Occurring in California (SR 1)
explanation: Each driver must file a Report of Traffic Accident Occurring in California (SR 1) with DMV. You must file a report whether or not you caused the collision.

questionText: You must report a collision to law enforcement within how many hours if anyone is injured or killed?
explanation: You must make a report to law enforcement within 24 hours of the collision if anyone is injured or killed. Your insurance agent, broker, or legal representative can also file the report.

questionText: The minimum insurance coverage required for death or injury to more than one person is:
explanation: Your insurance must cover at least $60,000 for death or injury to more than one person.

questionText: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.08% or higher if you are:
explanation: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.08% or higher if you are over 21 years old.

questionText: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.01% or higher if you are:
explanation: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.01% or higher if you are under 21 years old or at any age if you are on DUI probation.

questionText: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.04% or higher if you:
answerB: Drive a vehicle that requires a commercial driver's license
answerD: Have had your license for less than one year
explanation: It is illegal to drive with a BAC of 0.04% or higher if you drive a vehicle that requires a commercial driver's license or if you are driving a passenger for hire.

questionText: Children who are under 2 years old, under 40 pounds, AND under 3 feet 4 inches tall must be secured in:
answerB: A rear-facing child passenger restraint system
explanation: Children who are under 2 years old, under 40 pounds, AND under 3 feet 4 inches tall must be secured in a rear-facing child passenger restraint system.

questionText: A child in a rear-facing child passenger restraint system may not ride:
answerB: In the front seat of an airbag-equipped vehicle
explanation: A child in a rear-facing child passenger restraint system may not ride in the front seat of an airbag-equipped vehicle.

questionText: Children who are under 8 years old, or who are less than 4 feet 9 inches tall, must be secured in a child passenger restraint system in:
explanation: Children who are under 8 years old, or who are less than 4 feet 9 inches tall, must be secured in a child passenger restraint system in a rear seat.

questionText: Children who are 8 years old or older, or at least 4 feet 9 inches tall:
answerA: Do not need a seat belt
answerB: May use a properly secured safety belt
answerC: Must still use a child safety seat
answerD: Can sit in the front seat without a seat belt
explanation: Children who are 8 years old or older, or at least 4 feet 9 inches tall, may use a properly secured safety belt that meets federal standards.

questionText: If your passenger is under 16 years old and not wearing a seat belt:
answerA: Only the passenger can get a ticket
answerC: No one can get a ticket
answerD: Only the parent can get a ticket
explanation: You and your passengers must wear seat belts. You can get a ticket if you do not. If your passenger is under 16 years old, you can also get a ticket if they are not wearing their seat belt.

questionText: The shoulder harness of a seat belt should be worn:
explanation: Wear the shoulder harness across your shoulder and chest. There should be little to no slack. Do not wear the shoulder belt under your arm or behind your back.

questionText: The lap belt should be adjusted so that it:
answerB: Is snug and lies low across your hips
explanation: Adjust the lap belt so that it is snug and lies low across your hips. Otherwise, you might slide out of the belt in a crash.

questionText: If you are pregnant, you should wear the lap belt:
answerC: As low as possible under your abdomen
explanation: If you are pregnant, wear the lap belt as low as possible under your abdomen. Place the shoulder strap between your breasts and to the side of your abdomen's bulge.

questionText: When you buy a vehicle, you have how many days to transfer ownership to your name?
explanation: When you buy a vehicle, you have 10 days to transfer ownership to your name.

questionText: Traffic convictions and collisions stay on your record for:
explanation: Traffic convictions and collisions stay on your record for 36 months or longer, depending on the type of conviction.

questionText: You can attend traffic violator school once in any:
explanation: If you are given a one-point traffic violation, the judge may offer you the choice to attend a traffic violator school. You can do this once in any 18-month period.

questionText: DMV will revoke your driving privilege if you are convicted of:
answerB: Hit-and-run or reckless driving that resulted in injury
explanation: DMV will revoke your driving privilege if you are convicted of a hit-and-run or reckless driving that resulted in injury.

questionText: What must you show at the end of your license suspension or revocation to get a replacement driver's license?
answerA: Proof of financial responsibility (such as SR 22/SR 1P)
answerB: A completion certificate from driving school
explanation: At the end of your suspension or revocation, you may apply for a replacement driver's license. You must show proof of financial responsibility (such as SR 22/SR 1P).

questionText: If convicted of a DUI, your driving privilege will be suspended or revoked for:
explanation: If you are convicted of a DUI, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege for one year.

questionText: If convicted of a DUI, you may be sentenced to up to how many months in jail?
explanation: If you are convicted of a DUI, you may be sentenced to up to six months in jail.

questionText: If arrested for DUI, the law enforcement officer may take your driver's license and give you a temporary driver's license for:
explanation: If you are arrested for DUI, the law enforcement officer may take your driver's license and give you a temporary driver's license for 30 days.

questionText: After a DUI arrest, you may request a DMV administrative hearing within how many days?
explanation: If you are arrested for DUI, you may request a DMV administrative hearing within 10 days from the date of your arrest.

questionText: For a behind-the-wheel drive test, the vehicle's horn must be loud enough to be heard from a distance of at least:
explanation: The horn must be designed for the vehicle, in proper working condition, and loud enough to be heard from a distance of at least 200 feet.

questionText: For a behind-the-wheel drive test, there must be at least how much clearance between the brake pedal and the floorboard when depressed?
explanation: There must be at least one inch of clearance between the bottom of the brake pedal and the floorboard when depressed.

questionText: For a behind-the-wheel drive test, you must have at least how many rearview mirrors?
explanation: You must have at least two rearview mirrors. One of them must be on the left side of your vehicle.

questionText: When you are in a collision, your vehicle stops. But you keep moving at:
answerA: A slower speed than you were traveling
answerB: The same speed you were traveling
answerC: A faster speed than you were traveling
answerD: Half the speed you were traveling
explanation: When you are in a collision, your vehicle stops. But you keep moving at the same speed you were traveling. You only stop when you hit the dashboard or windshield.

questionText: You must use your headlights when it is too dark to see from:
explanation: Use your headlights when it is too dark to see from 1,000 feet away.

questionText: What should you do if your vehicle hits a parked car and you cannot find the owner?
answerB: Wait for the owner to return
answerC: Leave a note with your name, phone number, and address and report to law enforcement
explanation: Try to find the owner if your vehicle hits or rolls into a parked car or other property. If you cannot find the owner, leave a note with your name, phone number, and address. Securely attach the note to the vehicle or property. Report the collision to law enforcement.

questionText: If you kill or injure an animal with your vehicle, you should:
answerB: Call the nearest humane society or law enforcement
answerC: Try to move the animal yourself
answerD: Wait for someone else to handle it
explanation: If you kill or injure an animal, call the nearest humane society or law enforcement. Do not try to move an injured animal.

questionText: Most information in your driver's record is available to the public, except:
answerB: Physical or mental conditions, address, and social security number
explanation: Most information in your driver's record is available to the public, except physical or mental conditions, address, and social security number.

questionText: The most common causes of collisions include:
explanation: The most common causes of collisions include driver distractions, unsafe speed, improper turns, not following right-of-way rules, not following stop signals and signs, driving on the wrong side of the road, and a vehicle traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic.

questionText: If a Notice of Priority Reexamination has the top box checked, you have how many working days to contact DMV?
explanation: If you receive a Notice of Priority Reexamination of Driver with a check mark in the top box, you have five working days to contact DMV to initiate the process or your driving privilege will be automatically suspended.

questionText: If a collision results in $1,000 in damage, or where anyone is injured or dies:
answerA: Only the at-fault driver must report it
answerB: It is your responsibility to report it to DMV regardless of fault
answerC: Only law enforcement can report it
explanation: If you are involved in a collision resulting in $1,000 in damage, or where anyone is injured or dies, it is your responsibility to report the collision to DMV. DMV will add it to your driver's record. It does not matter who caused the collision.

questionText: What will happen to your driving privilege if you fail to file a collision report?
explanation: Your driving privilege will be suspended if you fail to file a collision report when required.

questionText: When backing up in a straight line, you should first:
answerC: Do a traffic check by observing traffic and checking appropriate blind spots
explanation: To back up in a straight line, first do a traffic check by observing traffic and checking appropriate blind spots. Then signal, check your blind spots again by looking in your rearview mirror and over your shoulder for approaching vehicles and pedestrians, before beginning to back up.

questionText: Blind spots are usually located:
answerA: Directly in front of your vehicle
answerB: At the sides, slightly behind the driver
explanation: Every vehicle has blind spots. For most vehicles, the blind spots are at the sides, slightly behind the driver. Check your blind spots by looking over your right and left shoulders.

questionText: To parallel park, you should find a space at least how much longer than your vehicle?
explanation: To parallel park, first find a space at least three feet longer than your vehicle. When you find a space, turn on your signal and pull up alongside the vehicle in front of the space, leaving about two feet between vehicles.

questionText: When parallel parking, you should leave about how much space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of the space?
explanation: When you find a space, turn on your signal and pull up alongside the vehicle in front of the space, leaving about two feet between vehicles.

questionText: You may NOT carry anything in or on a passenger vehicle which extends beyond the fenders on the left side or more than how many inches beyond the fenders on the right side?
explanation: You must not carry anything in or on a passenger vehicle which extends beyond the fenders on the left side or more than 6 inches beyond the fenders on the right side.

questionText: You must NOT allow a person to ride in the back of a pickup or other truck unless:
answerB: The vehicle has secure seats and seat belts
explanation: You must not allow a person to ride in the back of a pickup or other truck unless the vehicle has secure seats and seat (safety) belts.

questionText: Never stop on the railroad tracks. If you do not have enough room to completely cross, you risk:
explanation: Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.

questionText: You must expect a train on any track:
answerB: Only if warning lights are flashing
answerC: At any time, traveling in either direction
answerD: Only if you hear a horn
explanation: Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction.

questionText: Which vehicles must stop before crossing railroad tracks?
answerB: Buses, school buses, and vehicles marked with a hazardous materials placard
explanation: Watch for vehicles that must stop before they cross train tracks. These vehicles include buses, school buses, and vehicles marked with a hazardous materials placard.

questionText: When it starts to rain on a hot day, the pavement can be very slippery because:
answerB: Oil and dust on the road's surface have not been washed away
answerD: The rain makes the pavement expand
explanation: When it starts to rain, the pavement can be very slippery. Slow down at the first sign of rain, drizzle, or snow on the road. This is especially true if it has been dry and hot for some time, because oil and dust on the road's surface have not been washed away.

questionText: To enter a bike lane when preparing to turn, you can do so within how many feet of the turn?
explanation: You can drive in a bike lane within 200 feet from the turn when preparing to make a right turn. Check for bicyclists in your blind spots before entering the bike lane.

questionText: You should enter a bike lane no more than how many feet before starting a turn?
explanation: Enter a bike lane no more than 200 feet before starting a turn.

questionText: When following a bicyclist, you should maintain a safe distance. When it is safe, the bicyclist should:
answerC: Move to a position that allows vehicles to pass
explanation: Drivers should follow at a safe distance. When it is safe, the bicyclist should move to a position that allows vehicles to pass.

questionText: Bicyclists must have fully functional:
explanation: As a bicyclist, you must have fully functional brakes.

questionText: What does an octagonal (8-sided) sign mean?
explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means STOP. You must make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line.

questionText: A pennant-shaped sign indicates:
explanation: A pennant-shaped sign warns you that you are entering a no-passing zone.

questionText: Orange signs indicate:
explanation: Orange signs are used for highway construction and maintenance zones to warn drivers of workers and work zones ahead.

questionText: What does a white rectangular sign typically communicate?
explanation: A white rectangular sign communicates many important rules you must obey.

questionText: Green signs on highways provide information about:
explanation: Green signs are guide signs that provide information or directions, such as directions to nearby towns or distances to destinations.

questionText: Brown signs indicate:
explanation: Brown signs indicate recreational areas or places of cultural interest, such as state parks or historic sites.

questionText: A red circle with a red line through it means:
explanation: A red circle with a red line through it indicates that the action shown inside the circle is prohibited.

questionText: What shape is a yield sign?
explanation: A yield sign is a downward-pointing triangle that tells you to slow down and be ready to stop to let other road users go first.

questionText: Blue and white signs indicate:
explanation: Blue and white signs indicate services for drivers, such as rest areas, hospitals, gas stations, and food.

questionText: If your accelerator sticks while driving, you should first:
explanation: If your accelerator sticks, shift into neutral to disengage the engine from the wheels, then use the brakes to slow down and pull safely off the road.

questionText: If you have a tire blowout while driving, you should:
answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly and gradually slow down
explanation: Hold the steering wheel with both hands, maintain your speed if possible, gradually release the accelerator, correct the steering to stabilize your vehicle, and once stabilized, continue to slow down and pull off the road where it's safe.

questionText: If you get stuck in snow or mud, you should first:
answerB: Shift into a low gear and keep the front wheels straight
explanation: If stuck in snow or mud, shift into a low gear and keep the front wheels straight to gain traction.

questionText: The California Highway Patrol Freeway Service Patrol (FSP) will:
answerA: Tow your vehicle to a repair shop
answerB: Provide a gallon of gas if you run out
explanation: FSP will provide a gallon of gas if you run out, jump start your vehicle if the battery is dead, and change a flat tire. They will not tow your vehicle to a private repair service or residence.

questionText: What should you do if you see a hazard or collision ahead?
answerC: Tap your brake lightly to flash your brake lights
explanation: Tapping your brakes lightly causes your brake lights to flash, warning drivers behind you of a hazard ahead. This gives them time to slow down safely.

questionText: If you must stop on a freeway, you should:
answerB: Pull over to the right shoulder
explanation: If your vehicle stops working on the freeway, safely pull over to the right shoulder, exit on the right side if you must get out, and stay inside your vehicle with your seat belt on until help arrives.

questionText: When approaching a vehicle that is stopped for an emergency, you should:
explanation: When approaching a stationary emergency vehicle with flashing emergency signal lights (hazard lights), move over and slow down.

questionText: You must never stop on railroad tracks. If you cannot completely cross, you risk:
explanation: Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.

questionText: Expect a train on any track:
answerB: At any time, traveling in either direction
answerC: Only when warning lights are flashing
explanation: Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction.

questionText: Which vehicles must stop before crossing railroad tracks?
answerB: Buses, school buses, and vehicles with hazardous materials placards
explanation: Watch for vehicles that must stop before they cross train tracks. These vehicles include buses, school buses, and vehicles marked with a hazardous materials placard.

questionText: When must you report a collision to law enforcement?
answerA: If anyone is injured or killed
answerC: Only if there's more than $5,000 in damage
explanation: You must make a report to law enforcement within 24 hours of the collision if anyone is injured or killed.

questionText: If you need to use emergency flashers, you should use them when:
answerB: Your vehicle is disabled or you see a hazard ahead
explanation: Use your emergency flashers if you can see a collision or hazard ahead, or if you need to stop because of vehicle trouble.

questionText: Carbon monoxide is dangerous because it is:
explanation: All gas-powered vehicles produce carbon monoxide, which is a deadly odorless gas released from a vehicle's exhaust pipe. Symptoms include tiredness, yawning, dizziness, nausea, headache, and ringing in the ears.

questionText: In extreme heat, you should:
explanation: In extreme heat, you should watch the temperature gauge, avoid driving at high speeds for long periods, and turn off the air conditioner.

questionText: When it rains after a dry spell, roads are most slippery:
explanation: When it starts to rain, the pavement can be very slippery for the first several minutes because oil and dust on the road's surface have not been washed away.

questionText: When passing a bicyclist, you should allow at least how much clearance?
explanation: When you cannot change lanes to pass a bicyclist, allow at least three feet between your vehicle and the bicyclist. If you cannot give three feet of space, do not pass until three feet of clearance can be given.

questionText: Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as:
explanation: Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicle drivers.

questionText: You should allow a safe following distance of how many seconds when following a motorcycle?
explanation: Allow a safe three-second following distance when following a motorcycle. This space will help you avoid hitting a motorcyclist if they brake suddenly or fall.

questionText: When a bus, streetcar, or trolley is stopped at a safety zone or traffic light, you may pass at no more than:
explanation: When a bus, streetcar, or trolley is stopped at a safety zone or traffic light, you may pass at no more than 10 mph.

questionText: You must not follow within how many feet of any emergency vehicle with its siren or flashing lights on?
explanation: It is against the law to follow within 300 feet of any fire engine, law enforcement vehicle, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle when their siren or flashing lights are on.

questionText: When driving near large trucks, you should avoid:
answerC: Changing lanes directly in front of them
explanation: When driving near large vehicles and trucks, do not drive in their blind spots, follow too closely, or change lanes directly in front of them. Large trucks need extra space to stop and have large blind spots.

questionText: Bicyclists must ride in which direction relative to traffic?
answerB: In the same direction as traffic
explanation: Bicyclists must ride in the same direction as traffic.

questionText: When driving a hybrid or electric vehicle near blind pedestrians, you should be especially careful because:
answerA: These vehicles are harder to control
answerB: Blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby
explanation: Be careful when you are turning or backing up. This is particularly important if you are driving a hybrid or electric vehicle because blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby.

questionText: You must not overtake and pass a light rail vehicle or streetcar on the left side unless:
answerA: You are on a one-way street
answerB: A traffic officer directs you to
answerC: The tracks are so close to the right side that you cannot pass on the right
explanation: Do not overtake and pass a light rail vehicle or streetcar on the left side unless: the tracks are so close to the right side that the passenger vehicle cannot pass on the right, you are on a one-way street, or a traffic officer directs you to pass on the left.

questionText: Safety zones are spaces set aside for:
answerB: Pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys
explanation: Safety zones are spaces set aside for pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys. Do not drive through a safety zone under any condition.

questionText: When a large truck is making a wide turn, you should:
answerA: Try to squeeze by on the right
answerC: Wait for the truck to complete the turn
explanation: Large vehicles and truck drivers must often swing wide to complete a turn. When you follow a large vehicle, look at its turn signals before you start to pass. Wait for the truck to complete the turn rather than trying to squeeze by.

questionText: Bicyclists traveling slower than the flow of traffic must ride:
answerC: As close as possible to the right curb or edge of the road
answerD: In the center of the lane
explanation: Bicyclists traveling slower than the flow of traffic must ride as close as possible to the right curb or edge of the road, unless passing, preparing to make a left turn, or avoiding hazards.

questionText: You should not stay in another driver's blind spot because:
answerB: They cannot see you and may change lanes into you
explanation: Do not stay in another driver's blind spot. They cannot see you and may change lanes into your vehicle.

questionText: When animals or livestock are near the road, you should:
answerC: Slow down and follow directions from the person in charge
explanation: If you see animals or livestock near the road, slow down or stop and proceed when it is safe. Be sure to follow directions from the person in charge of the animals.

questionText: It is against the law to intentionally scare:
explanation: Horse-drawn vehicles and people riding horses or other animals are allowed to share the road with motor vehicles. It is against the law to intentionally scare horses or livestock.

questionText: When sharing the road with light rail vehicles, you should:
answerA: Never turn in front of an approaching light rail vehicle
answerC: Check for approaching light rail vehicles before you turn across the tracks
explanation: To safely share the road with light rail vehicles: be aware of where they operate, never turn in front of an approaching light rail vehicle, maintain a safe distance, and check for approaching light rail vehicles before you turn across the tracks.

questionText: When driving near motorcycles, you should remember that:
answerA: They can stop faster than cars
answerB: They are easier to see than cars
answerC: Road conditions can cause motorcyclists to suddenly change speed or direction
explanation: Road conditions can cause motorcyclists to suddenly change speed or direction. Be aware and give them space.

questionText: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes:
answerA: Have the right-of-way at all times
answerC: Can only cross at marked crosswalks
answerD: Must wait for a green light
explanation: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes have the right-of-way at all times. These pedestrians are partially or totally blind. Do not honk your horn at a blind person.

questionText: When possible, you should give a motorcycle:
explanation: Whenever possible, give a motorcycle the full lane. It is legal to share lanes with motorcycles (lane splitting), but giving them the full lane is safer.

questionText: Before opening your car door next to traffic, you should:
answerD: Wait for all traffic to pass
explanation: Check for motorcyclists and bicyclists before you open your door next to traffic. Motorcycles and bicycles are smaller and harder to see.

questionText: When you pass a large vehicle, you should:
answerB: Pass as quickly as possible on the left side
answerC: Always pass a large vehicle on the left side and move ahead of it
answerD: Drive alongside it as long as possible
explanation: Always pass a large vehicle on the left side. After you pass the large vehicle or truck, move ahead of it. Driving alongside a large vehicle makes it hard for the driver to avoid dangers in the road.

questionText: Bicyclists must have which of the following equipment on their bicycle?
explanation: Bicyclists must have fully functional brakes. At night, bicycles must have a front lamp with a white light visible from 300 feet, a rear red reflector or light visible from 500 feet, and reflectors on pedals, shoes, or ankles visible from 200 feet.

questionText: When parallel parking, you should find a space at least how much longer than your vehicle?
explanation: To parallel park, first find a space at least three feet longer than your vehicle.

questionText: When parallel parking, you should leave about how much space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of the space?
explanation: When you find a space, turn on your signal and pull up alongside the vehicle in front of the space, leaving about two feet between vehicles.

questionText: After parallel parking, your vehicle should be within how many inches of the curb?
explanation: When parallel parking, your vehicle should be parallel and within 18 inches of the curb.

questionText: When parking on a hill with a curb, headed downhill, you should:
answerA: Turn your wheels away from the curb
answerB: Turn your wheels toward the curb
answerD: Turn your wheels sharply to the left
explanation: When parking headed downhill, turn your front wheels into the curb or right toward the side of the road.

questionText: When parking uphill with a curb, you should:
answerA: Turn your wheels toward the curb
answerB: Turn your wheels away from the curb
explanation: When parking headed uphill, turn your front wheels away from the curb (left towards the center of the road) and let your vehicle roll back a few inches so the wheel gently touches the curb.

questionText: When parking on a hill with no curb, you should turn your wheels:
explanation: When parking headed either uphill or downhill when there is no curb, turn the wheels to the right so the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of a fire hydrant?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within 15 feet of a fire hydrant or fire station driveway.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of a crosswalk?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within 20 feet of an unmarked or marked crosswalk, or within 15 feet of a crosswalk where a curb extension is present.

questionText: You must not park within how many feet of a sidewalk ramp for disabled persons?
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle within three feet of a sidewalk ramp for disabled persons.

questionText: A white-painted curb means you can:
answerB: Stop only long enough to pick up or drop off passengers
explanation: White curbs mean stop only long enough to pick up or drop off passengers.

questionText: A green-painted curb means:
explanation: Green curbs mean park for a limited time. The time limit may be posted on signs or painted on the curb.

questionText: A yellow-painted curb is used for:
answerB: Loading and unloading passengers and freight
explanation: Yellow curbs are for loading and unloading passengers and freight. Do not stop longer than the time posted. If you drive a noncommercial vehicle, you are usually required to stay with your vehicle.

questionText: A blue-painted curb is reserved for:
answerC: A disabled person with a special placard or license plate
explanation: Blue curbs are for parking for a disabled person or someone driving a disabled person with a special placard or special license plate.

questionText: Never park or leave your vehicle:
answerA: On a marked or unmarked crosswalk
answerB: On a sidewalk or partially blocking a sidewalk
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle on a marked or unmarked crosswalk, on a sidewalk, partially blocking a sidewalk, or in front of a driveway.

questionText: You must not park in a tunnel or on a bridge:
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle in a tunnel or on a bridge, unless permitted by signs.

questionText: It is illegal to park in a space designated for zero-emission vehicles unless:
answerA: You are only parking for 5 minutes
answerB: You are driving a zero-emission vehicle
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle in a space designated for parking or fueling zero-emission vehicles, unless you are driving a zero-emission vehicle.

questionText: You must not park between a safety zone and curb:
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle between a safety zone and curb.

questionText: Double parking is:
answerB: Legal if you stay in the vehicle
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle double parked. This is illegal at all times.

questionText: The crosshatched (diagonal lines) area next to a designated disabled parking space is:
answerB: An access aisle that you must never park in
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle in the crosshatched (diagonal lines) area next to a designated disabled parking space. This area is reserved for wheelchair access and vehicle loading equipment.

questionText: When backing up in a straight line, you should back for how many vehicle lengths while remaining within three feet of the curb?
explanation: When backing up in a straight line, back for three vehicle lengths while remaining within three feet of the curb.

questionText: When parking on a sloping driveway, you should:
answerA: Turn the wheels so the vehicle will not roll into the street
explanation: On a sloping driveway, turn the wheels so the vehicle will not roll into the street, leave the vehicle in park and set the parking brake.

questionText: Before exiting your vehicle after parking, you should:
answerB: Look carefully for passing vehicles, bicycles, and motorcycles
explanation: Before you exit your vehicle, look carefully for passing vehicles, bicycles, and motorcycles. Exit when safe.

questionText: When parallel parking, at what angle should you back into the space?
explanation: When parallel parking, turn your steering wheel to back into the space at about a 45-degree angle.

questionText: After parallel parking, you should straighten out when your rear wheel is within how many inches of the curb?
explanation: Begin turning the steering wheel away from the curb when your rear wheel is within 18 inches of the curb.

questionText: When parking, you must always:
answerD: Turn the wheels to the left
explanation: When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to equipment failure. Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission.

questionText: You may legally park in front of a driveway:
answerA: If it is your own driveway
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle on a sidewalk, partially blocking a sidewalk, or in front of a driveway. Blocking any driveway is illegal.

questionText: It is illegal to park in front of or on a curb that provides wheelchair access to a sidewalk:
answerC: Unless you have a disabled placard
explanation: Never park or leave your vehicle in front of or on a curb that provides wheelchair access to a sidewalk.

questionText: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes must be given:
answerC: The same right-of-way as other pedestrians
answerD: Extra time to cross but not priority
explanation: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes have the right-of-way at all times. These pedestrians are partially or totally blind. Do not honk your horn at a blind person.

questionText: When a blind person pulls in their cane and steps away from an intersection, this usually means:
explanation: When a blind person pulls in their cane and steps away from the intersection, this gesture usually means you may go.

questionText: If two vehicles meet on a steep narrow road and neither can pass, which vehicle has the right-of-way?
explanation: If two vehicles meet on a steep narrow road and neither vehicle can pass, the vehicle facing uphill has the right-of-way. The vehicle facing downhill has more control when backing up the hill. The vehicle facing downhill should back up until the vehicle going uphill can pass.

questionText: A person with a disability using a tricycle, quadricycle, or wheelchair for transportation is considered:
explanation: A person with a disability using a tricycle, quadricycle, or wheelchair for transportation is considered a pedestrian.

questionText: When there is a pedestrian crossing a roadway, you must:
answerC: Use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow them to safely finish crossing
explanation: When there is a pedestrian crossing a roadway, you must use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow the pedestrian to safely finish crossing. If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line.

questionText: Pedestrians always have the right-of-way:
explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line and allow pedestrians to cross the street.

questionText: When crossing a sidewalk to enter or exit a driveway, you must:
answerB: Yield to any pedestrian on the sidewalk
explanation: When pedestrians are on the sidewalk, they have the right-of-way. If a driver is crossing a sidewalk, perhaps when entering or exiting a driveway, they are required to yield to any pedestrian on the sidewalk.

questionText: At an uncontrolled intersection (no signs or signals), you should:
answerB: Slow down and be ready to stop to yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and traffic already in the intersection
answerC: Speed up to get through first
explanation: Uncontrolled intersections have no traffic lights or traffic signs. When you approach an uncontrolled intersection, you need to slow down and be ready to stop to yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and traffic already in the intersection.

questionText: If a pedestrian makes eye contact with you at a crosswalk, they are:
answerB: Ready to cross the street - you should yield
explanation: If a pedestrian makes eye contact with you, they are ready to cross the street. Yield to the pedestrian.

questionText: You should allow extra time for pedestrians who:
explanation: Always allow pedestrians enough time to safely cross a street as some groups such as seniors, people with small children, and people with disabilities may require extra time.

questionText: Do not pass a vehicle stopped at a crosswalk because:
answerB: You may not be able to see a pedestrian crossing the street
answerC: The other driver might get angry
answerD: You might scratch the other vehicle
explanation: Do not pass a vehicle stopped at a crosswalk. You may not be able to see a pedestrian crossing the street.

questionText: When you must obey directions from school safety patrols or crossing guards:
explanation: When near schools, be sure to obey school safety patrols or crossing guards' directions at all times. Their instructions take priority to ensure the safety of pedestrians, especially children.

questionText: A funeral procession:
answerA: Must yield to all other traffic
answerB: Has the right-of-way and is led by a traffic officer
answerC: Should be interrupted if you're in a hurry
explanation: A funeral procession is led by a traffic officer and has the right-of-way. All vehicles taking part in the procession have windshield markers to identify them and have their headlights on. You can be ticketed if you interrupt a funeral procession.

questionText: When approaching a stationary emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
explanation: When approaching a stationary emergency vehicle with flashing emergency signal lights (hazard lights), move over and slow down.

questionText: When you see or hear an emergency vehicle with lights and sirens, you should:
answerA: Speed up to get out of the way
answerB: Stop in the middle of the road
answerC: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop
