explanation: Give the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed.

questionText: If you are in an intersection when you see an emergency vehicle approaching, you should:
answerC: Continue through the intersection, then drive to the right and stop
explanation: If you're in an intersection, wait until you have cleared it before pulling over to the right.

questionText: When should you give up your legal right-of-way?
answerC: Only when a police officer directs you to
explanation: Never assume that other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Give up your right-of-way when it will help prevent collisions.

questionText: At a T intersection without STOP or YIELD signs:
answerA: The turning vehicles have the right-of-way
answerB: Vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians on the through road have the right-of-way
answerC: Whoever arrives first has the right-of-way
answerD: The larger vehicle has the right-of-way
explanation: At T intersections without STOP or YIELD signs, vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians on the through road (continuing to go straight) have the right-of-way.

questionText: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to:
answerC: Any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous
answerD: No one if you have a green light
explanation: When turning left at an intersection, check for pedestrians and give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous. Look both ways (left-right-left) and begin your turn when it is safe.

questionText: When making a right turn, you should always:
answerB: Check for pedestrians crossing the street and motorcycles and bicycles riding next to you
explanation: When turning right, always check for pedestrians crossing the street, and motorcycles and bicycles riding next to you.

questionText: At an intersection with a green traffic signal light, you should:
answerB: Proceed with caution - pedestrians have the right-of-way
answerC: Speed up to beat the yellow light
answerD: Stop and wait for a green arrow
explanation: A green traffic signal light means proceed with caution. Pedestrians have the right-of-way.

questionText: When entering traffic from a stopped position, you must:
answerB: Proceed with caution and yield to traffic already occupying the lanes
explanation: When entering traffic, you must proceed with caution and yield to the traffic already occupying the lanes.

questionText: At a roundabout, you must yield to:
answerB: All traffic already in the roundabout
explanation: You must yield to all traffic already in the roundabout before entering. If you miss your exit, continue around until you return to it.

questionText: Vehicles driving near horses or livestock should:
answerC: Slow down and follow directions from the person in charge
answerD: Flash lights to scare them away
explanation: If you see animals or livestock near the road, slow down or stop and proceed when it is safe. Be sure to follow directions from the person in charge of the animals.

questionText: At an officially designated equestrian crossing, drivers must:
answerD: Speed up to pass before the horses
explanation: Drivers must yield to horses at an officially designated equestrian crossing.

questionText: If vehicles arrive at an intersection at the same time:
answerA: The vehicle on the left has the right-of-way
answerB: The vehicle on the right has the right-of-way
answerC: The larger vehicle has the right-of-way
answerD: The faster vehicle has the right-of-way
explanation: If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.

questionText: The vehicle that arrives to an intersection first:
explanation: The vehicle that arrives to the intersection first has the right-of-way. Other vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians must wait for the person who has the right-of-way.

questionText: When approaching a crosswalk with flashing lights:
answerB: Ignore the lights if no pedestrians are visible
answerC: Look for pedestrians and be prepared to stop whether or not the lights are flashing
answerD: Only stop if the lights are red
explanation: Some crosswalks have flashing lights. Whether or not the lights are flashing, look for pedestrians and be prepared to stop.

questionText: When backing up, you should:
answerB: Check for pedestrians, especially in areas with high foot traffic
answerD: Back up as quickly as possible
explanation: When backing up, check for pedestrians, especially in areas with high foot traffic. Use your mirrors and backup cameras to help you see behind you, and be aware that pedestrians may be walking behind your car.

questionText: When is it legal to block an intersection?
answerB: If you have a green light
answerC: Never - it is against the law
explanation: It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.

questionText: Factors that affect blood alcohol concentration (BAC) include:
answerC: Amount and kind of food in the stomach
explanation: Many factors affect BAC including: amount of alcohol consumed, strength or proof of alcohol, length of time over which alcohol is consumed, amount and kind of food in the stomach, weight of the person drinking, and physical and emotional condition of the person drinking.

questionText: BAC stands for:
explanation: BAC stands for Blood Alcohol Concentration. It measures a person's level of intoxication by determining the percentage of alcohol in their blood.

questionText: If you are under 21 and are found with a BAC of 0.01% or higher:
answerB: You will lose your license for one year
answerD: You will only get a fine
explanation: If a driver under 21 is found with a BAC of just 0.01%, they will lose their license for a whole year. This underscores the importance of a zero-tolerance policy for underage drinking and driving.

questionText: California's implied consent law means that by driving, you agree to:
answerB: Take a chemical test if lawfully arrested for suspected DUI
explanation: California has an implied consent law. This means, just by driving, you agree to take a chemical test if you are lawfully arrested for a suspected DUI.

questionText: If you refuse to take a chemical test when suspected of DUI:
answerC: Your driving privilege will be revoked
answerD: You only pay a small fine
explanation: If you refuse the test, your driving privileges will be revoked. If a law enforcement officer thinks you are driving while under the influence of drugs or alcohol, they have the right to ask you to take a blood or urine test. If you refuse to take one, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege for one year.

questionText: When suspected of DUI, a law enforcement officer may ask you to take:
answerC: A breathalyzer OR a blood test - you have the option
explanation: If you are pulled over and suspected of driving while intoxicated, the officer will ask you to submit to a test, and under this law, must give you the option of taking a breathalyzer or a blood test.

questionText: If an officer suspects drug use after you take a breathalyzer:
answerB: They can require you to take an additional test
answerD: Only a judge can order additional tests
explanation: If you choose the breathalyzer, but the officer suspects possible drug use, they are lawfully able to advise you that you must submit to an additional test.

questionText: A urine test for DUI is allowed only if:
answerB: Both breath and blood tests are unavailable, the driver is a hemophiliac, or uses anticoagulant medication
explanation: A urine test is allowed only if both other tests are unavailable, the driver is a hemophiliac, or the driver uses an anticoagulant medication.

questionText: For a first offense DUI that did not result in injury, you can be jailed for up to:
explanation: For a 1st offense DUI, potentially no additional punishment will be issued; however, you can be jailed for up to 48 hours (2 days).

questionText: For a second offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional:
explanation: For a 2nd offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional 96 hours (4 days) in jail.

questionText: For a third offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional:
explanation: For a 3rd offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional 10 days in jail.

questionText: For a fourth offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional:
explanation: For a 4th offense DUI, you can be sentenced to an additional 18 days in jail.

questionText: If convicted of DUI with injury, additional time can be served in:
answerB: State prison depending on severity of injury
explanation: If you are convicted of DUI with injury (your drunk driving resulted in the injury of someone in your car, another car, or a pedestrian), additional time can be added and can be required to be served in a state prison depending on the severity of injury.

questionText: Alcohol is classified as a:
explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that affects your entire nervous system.

questionText: What percentage of alcohol is eliminated by the liver through oxidation?
explanation: The liver takes care of about 90% of alcohol through a process called oxidation. Less than 10% is eliminated by the kidneys, lungs, and skin, and two to five percent is passed unchanged by bodily functions.

questionText: Even if your BAC is below legal limits:
answerA: It is always safe to drive
answerB: It may not be safe to drive as almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol even at levels lower than the legal limit
answerC: You cannot be arrested for DUI
answerD: You are guaranteed to pass a field sobriety test
explanation: Even if your BAC is below legal limits, that does not mean it is safe for you to drive. Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit. Depending on how badly you are impaired, you may be arrested and convicted of a DUI even without a BAC measurement.

questionText: It is illegal to drink alcohol, smoke or eat a cannabis product:
answerA: While driving or riding as a passenger
explanation: It is illegal to drink any alcohol, to smoke or eat a cannabis product while you are driving or riding as a passenger in a vehicle.

questionText: If carrying alcohol or cannabis in your vehicle, the container must be:
answerB: Sealed and unopened, or in the trunk
explanation: If you are carrying alcohol or cannabis in your vehicle, the container must be sealed and unopened. If it is open, you must keep the container in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit. It is also illegal to keep an open container of alcohol in your glove box.

questionText: If you are under 21, you may carry alcohol in your vehicle only if:
answerB: An individual who is 21 years old or older is with you
answerC: The container is sealed and unopened AND someone 21 or older is with you
explanation: If you are under 21 years old, you may not carry any alcohol beverage inside a vehicle unless an individual who is 21 years old or older is with you. The container must be full, sealed, and unopened.

questionText: If you are under 21 and caught with alcohol in your vehicle, law enforcement can:
answerB: Impound your vehicle for up to 30 days
explanation: If you are caught with alcohol in your vehicle, law enforcement can impound your vehicle for up to 30 days. The court may fine you and suspend your driver's license for one year.

questionText: If an officer suspects you (under 21) of consuming alcohol, they can require you to take:
answerB: A hand-held breath test, PAS, or another chemical test
explanation: If a law enforcement officer suspects you of consuming alcohol, they can require you to take a hand-held breath test, PAS, or another chemical test.

questionText: If your PAS (Preliminary Alcohol Screening) shows a BAC of 0.05% or higher (under 21):
answerC: The officer may require you to take a breath or blood test
explanation: If your PAS shows a BAC of 0.05% or higher, the officer may require you to take a breath or blood test.

questionText: If convicted of a DUI with a BAC of 0.01% or higher (under 21), DMV may:
answerB: Revoke your driving privilege for one year
explanation: If you are convicted of a DUI with a BAC of 0.01% or higher, DMV may revoke your driving privilege for one year. You must also complete a licensed DUI program.

questionText: Alcohol affects:
explanation: Alcohol impairs judgment, awareness, vision, and reaction time, and increases the likelihood of accidents.

questionText: A young driver (under 21) with a BAC of only 0.02 to 0.05% is:
answerB: At least seven times more likely to be killed than a sober driver
answerD: Below the legal limit so no risk
explanation: A young driver with a BAC (Blood Alcohol Concentration) of only 0.02 to 0.05 percent is at least seven times more likely to be killed than a sober driver.

questionText: Prescription and over-the-counter medications:
answerB: Can make you an unsafe driver
answerC: Are always safe to take before driving
explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications can make you an unsafe driver. It is your responsibility to know the effects of the medications you take. Make sure you read medication labels and know the effects of any drug you use.

questionText: Driving under the influence of drugs, whether legal or illegal:
answerA: Is only illegal if you get in an accident
answerB: Is illegal if it affects your ability to drive safely
